title: 1998 AHSME Problem 19
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many triangles have area 10 and vertices at (-5,0),(5,0) and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(5\\cos \\theta, 5\\sin \\theta)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some angle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\theta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 2
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Letters A,B,C, and D represent four different digits selected from 0, 1, 2, ... , 9. If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\frac{ A+B}{C+D} "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"is an integer that is as large as possible, what is the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Simple logic..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A = 9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B = 8"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A and B being the 2 largest numbers in the set"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C = 0"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"D = 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C and D being the 2 smallest numbers in the set"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(C+D) = 1, so any number can be placed in replacement of A and B other than 0 and 1"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then, the highest possible is needed so the 2 largest numbers will replace A and B, numbers 8 and 9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So (A+B) = 17"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(8+9) / (0+1) = 17","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{17}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the answer"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The numerator is independent of the integer (practically), since the largest numbers will go in the numerator. You dont need to determine the denominator, or do any division.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hey yo pals,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As the selected range of A,B,C & D are [0.9],"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"as (A+B) / (C+D) = maximum possible value,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C+D = the lowest value, since for the lowest value of C+D=1,(C=0, D=1 or D=0, C=1),"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+ B / 1 = maximum possible value,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A + B = 8 + 9 = 17 as A = 8, B=9 or A=9, B=8 ,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"therefore, maximum possible value = 17,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"thanks....."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 1998 AHSME Problem 20
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Three cards, each with a positive integer written on it, are lying face-down on a table. Casey, Stacy, and Tracy are told that"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(a) the numbers are all different"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(b) they sum to 13"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(c) they are in increasing order, left to right"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, Casey looks at the number on the leftmost card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Then Tracy looks at the number on the rightmost card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Finally, Stacy looks at the number on the middle card and says, "I don't have enough information to determine the other two numbers." Assume that each person knows that the other two reason perfectly and hears their comments. What number is on the middle card?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
It\quad is\quad not\quad hard\quad to\quad check\quad that\quad there\quad are\quad only\quad 8\quad possible\quad outcomes,\quad which\quad are\\ (1,2,10),\quad (1,3,9),\quad (1,4,8),\quad (1,5,7)\\ (2,3,8),\quad (2,4,7),\quad (2,5,6)\\ (3,4,6)\\ \\ Casey's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (3,4,6)\quad \\ because\quad only\quad 1\quad possible\quad outcome\quad with\quad 3\quad on\quad the\quad leftmost\quad card.\\ \\ Tracy's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (2,5,6),\quad (1,2,10)\quad and\quad (1,3,9)\\ because\quad only\quad 1\quad possible\quad outcome\quad with\quad that\quad number\quad on\quad the\quad rightmost\quad card.\\ \\ Stacy's\quad IDK\quad rules\quad out\quad (1,5,7)\quad and\quad (2,3,8).\\ \\ The\quad remaining\quad possible\quad outcomes\quad (1,4,8)\quad and\quad (2,4,7)\quad both\quad have\quad 4\quad on\quad the\quad middle\quad card."}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
